titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. IV:15.Mr H. Johnson the Senator from Louisiana paid us a visit this Morning. At the Office Mrs Cornell came with Bestor to enquire if there was an answer from the President concerning her Son— There was none— This Evening Mr Petry called for several numbers of the Journal des
Dames which he had lent to Mrs Adams, and the Abbé Correa came and took leave— He goes tomorrow to Wilmington, and to Philadelphia, if the yellow fever, of which there have been three or four cases there almost every day these five or six weeks, should disappear. The Abbe has been many years in this Country first as a fugitive from the fangs of the Inquisition, and afterwards as Minister Plenipotentiary which he has been these four or five years. He is now seventy years of age, and is yet full of spirits, vivacity and wit. He is among the men I have known, one of the most entertaining conversation. His political situation here for the last two years has been unpleasant; continually remonstrating against the Baltimore Piracies, under Artigan Colours, and hitherto with little success— The Abbe is apparently well satisfied with the prospect of going to a comfortable office in Brazil.

2. IV: My occupation absorbs my attention to such a degree, that I this morning gave a signal example of carelessness. At the Office, I found a Note from my old Classmate at College W. A. Barron, who is a Captain of Engineers in the army, mentioning that he had called to see me; but without saying where he was to be found. I conclude he was merely passing through the City. I wrote Letters to R. Rush, and to a Mr Wolf at Philadelphia, and having gone into the Library to consult some books, was there so late that the watchman to the building thinking me gone, locked me in— It was passed six O’Clock when I got home to dinner. Mr T. Cook was here part of the Evening.

3. IV:45. We all attended Church at Mr M’Cormick’s, and he read prayers for the 14th. Sunday after Trinity; but the Sermon was preached by a Stranger whose name was unknown to us all. His text was from Hebrews XII:14 “Follow peace with all Men, and holiness, without which no man shall see the Lord.” The discourse was not deficient in good sense, but the delivery was so bad, at once cold and canting that it was almost ludicrous. I have now neither eyes nor ears for any thing but weights and measures, and devote the Sundays to them almost as much as the week-days— Mrs Adams with the children spent the Evening at her sister Smith’s.Mr. A. Kerr passed it chiefly with me— The heat renders it yet exceedingly irksome to me to read, and impossible to write by evening candle-light— I am barely able to get through the daily newspapers with it.

4. IV:15. I undertook again this day that which I have repeatedly attempted before, but in which I have never been able permanently to persevere—that is to attend at the office as early as ten or eleven of the Morning, and to return from it to my house between three and four in the afternoon— I attended this Morning at ten and came home at four— Mr Bennet of Alexandria, who applies for the appointment of Consul at the Port of Pernambuco in Brazil, came to enquire if there was an answer from the President concerning his application— The President had given some encouragement in favour of a Mr Bibby of New-York. But as there are several other applications the President has concluded to postpone the appointment and wait. Mr Bestor came again in behalf of Mrs Cornell— The President has directed in the case of her Son a reprieve for sixty days; to give time for more applications in the young man’s behalf. I told Bestor that this reprieve would be despatched to the Marshal for the District of Rhode-Island this day, as it was. I received a Letter from the President giving notice of his intention to leave his present residence at Highland Albemarle County, Virginia, to return to his other place at Oakhill, Loudoun County, about thirty miles from this City, the day after to-morrow.

5. III:30. My morning hours are now employed with perfectly regular occupation; immediately after rising and lighting my candle I sit down to my table and write three pages of the draft for a Report upon Weights and Measures: this fixes me till nine or ten O’Clock; sometimes later, and with the interval of an hour to breakfast— Other unavoidable avocations steal small portions of time; and I am now attempting to be early at the Office—to effect which I was obliged this morning to take my papers with me, and write there— I received a despatch of 14. July from A. Gallatin; after Mr Hyde de Neuville had arrived in Paris. Gallatin encloses a
copy of a very able note that he had sent to Baron Pasquier the French Minister of foreign affairs concerning the Tonnage duty upon French Vessels coming into the Ports of the United States laid at the last Session of Congress, but he complains, that the measures of Congress which he had recommended were not adopted, but others more irritating to France, and also that his Letters were published. The Law of Congress was certainly a blister, and his Letters were not oil to soften its application. The commencement of the Law was fixed too soon, and the duty was too high— But France had been so sluggish and so deaf to friendly representations, that it was necessary to awaken her by acts of another tone. I answered Letters from Judge Johnson of the Supreme Court, and from T. Parker and others applying for the appointment of U.S. District Attorney in South-Carolina.

6. III:15. As I was going to the Office this morning I found Edward Wyer, the Consul at Hamburg, and now absent upon leave— He was here almost the whole of last Winter and has continued here till now, he says on account of an Administration upon the Estate of his brother who died at Sea bound from New-Orleans to Europe, and left an inheritance divisible between Edward, and his Sister, Mrs Babcock. He came soon after to the Office and remained there upwards of two hours— I weighed a quantity of Water and of Wheat without sufficiently attending to the result of the experiments— Of a half bushel of wheat that I procured the heaviest kernels that could be selected, weighed 32 kernels to the Troy Penny-weight— The average of the best kernels was 34 to a Penny-weight, and the average of all 40 to a Penny-weight— I had borrowed a wine Gallon, which contained exactly four of my Quart Pots and a Peck and half-peck measure of which the latter being the corn Gallon contained 8 Pounds Ounces avoir dupois— By measuring the wine gallon as the frustum of a Cone I found its cubic contents to be 234 inches but the admeasurement must have been erroneous— I wasted thus too much of my Office time, but wrote to the President.

7. III:Mrs Adams with her Sister Smith, went this morning to pay a visit of ten days to their Relations at Frederick. She went at six O’Clock and Elizabeth had gone off in the Stage at three. Mary Hellen went yesterday to pass this time at her Aunt Frye’s. General Parker was at the Office, with another Letter from Byers of New-York concerning the new discovered land South of Cape Horn— He is extremely anxious to have a public ship sent to protect their contemplated settlement and Sealing Ships— The President had written me that he was willing a public ship should be sent, but desired I would consult about it with the Secretary of the Navy; but he is absent even from New-York— Parker said he would go and see B Homans the chief Clerk of the Navy Department concerning it.— W. Lee came with a Letter from M. M. Noah, Editor of the New-York Advocate, a Jew, who was once Consul at Tunis, recalled for Indiscretions, and who has published a Book of Travels against Mr Madison and Mr Monroe— He has great projects for colonizing Jews in this Country; and wants to be sent as Charge d’Affaires to Vienna, for the promotion of them— He is an incorrect and very ignorant but sprightly writer, and as a partizan Editor of a Newspaper has considerable power. He urges with great earnestness, his merits in supporting the administration as a title to the President’s favour. He is like all the Editors of Newspapers in this Country, who have any talent, an author to be let.— There is not one of them whose friendship is worth buying, nor one whose enmity is not formidable— They are a sort of Assassins who sit with loaded Blunderbusses at the corner of Streets, and fire them off for hire or for sport, at any passenger whom they select— They are principally foreigners but Noah is a native— He is Salaried at a low rate by the Anti-Clintonian Tammanies at New-York, to keep up a constant fire against his Administration, and Noah pretends that this is serving the General Government because Clinton is a standing Presidential candidate and carries on an insidious War against Mr Monroe— Lee brought also another application for
the appointment of a Mr Ralston as commercial agent at Port au Prince; but there is one already appointed.— The Heat was excessive, day and Evening.

8. III: The heat of the Night is more oppressive than that of the day, and I scarcely obtain any sleep. I retire between eight and nine O’Clock in the Evening to bed, with the view of rising at three; but I awake between one and two, and cannot afterwards sleep again. This is an inconvenience I have always found when endeavouring to rise at an extraordinary early hour. I awake sooner than my time; and every day sooner than the day before, till I find myself too much weakened by broken rest. Young M’Kean was at the Office to ask for an answer to a Mr Wolf, who has a good for nothing claim upon the British Government of 26 years standing upon which he has written me three or four Letters, and his Counsel Dallas as many.— I answered all his Letters, last week. Mr Anderson the first Comptroller of the Treasury, came to consult me upon a question of Construction on the Navigation Act of the last Session of Congress— The Collector and the Merchants of New-York, differed upon it: my opinion was on the side of the Merchants, and he told me he had prepared his answer in the same aspect— The point was clear though on a first reading it had a different appearance. I received two despatches from C. S. Todd at the Island of Margaritta; the last a very long one with several enclosures. I spent about two hours in revising the Manuscript Journals of the Old Congress which are to be published, and which give me no small trouble—

9. III:15. I was roused in the Night between Midnight and one, and had no sleep afterwards. As the morning tide now serves, I bathed at seven this Morning with Charles in the Potowmack— At the Office I wrote to the President, and also to T. B. Waite at Boston, concerning the printing of the Secret Journals of the Old Congress. Perhaps a fourth part of the Manuscripts containing the Secret Journals consist of proceedings which were published in the Public Journals of the time— They are marked in the margin of the Manuscript Volumes with a p. The terms of the Resolutions of Congress, being to publish only the Secret Journals, I had directed that in copying the manuscripts all the parts marked with a p. should be omitted— But when I came to examine the copy I found that many of those parts were so essentially connected with the secret part, that it would scarcely be intelligible; especially as the old public Journals are quite out of Print. I have had copies made therefore of the omitted parts of the manuscript. I am now forwarding to Waite; but that has already taken 8 or 10 sheets of paper. I then took up one of the Volumes the manuscript of which has already been sent to Waite, to make reference to the dates and pages of the old printed Journals from which I shall direct him to take them; and after spending the best part of two days upon it I have reached only the year 1778 of the foreign Volume. It would be the drudgery of at least a fortnight; and I cannot spare the time— I shall give it over to Mr Brent, but he was absent this day from the Office. The heat continues oppressive.

10. III: I walked with Charles to Church, with the Thermometer at 88. but a fresh breeze from the Southwest. Mr M’Cormick read prayers for the 15th. Sunday after Trinity, and a Sermon from 1. Kings XVIII:21. “And Elijah came to all the people, and said, How long halt ye between two opinions? If the Lord be God, follow him: but if Baal, then follow him.” A good, but not a remarkable discourse. It gave a good historical account of that absurd condition of the Israelites, during which the worshiped the true God, and at the same time the Gods of the heathens; and applied it ingeniously to those who now think they can devote themselves at once to the Vanities and fashions of the world, and to the deity— After Church I visited at Dowson’sMr H. Johnson the Senator from Louisiana— The rest of the day and evening I passed at home, and made two or three ineffectual attempts to sit down to write. The heat made it insupportable, and I gave it up— But having received from J. Vaughan at Philadelphia, Lord Liverpool’s Letter to the King of England upon the Coins, with a request that I would return it as soon as possible, I gave it a cursory perusal, and marked passages to be
extracted from it. I find his information much to my purpose— But my Journal is running sadly to arrears— Since the first of the Month, I have scarcely written a line, and have not yet closed the Month of August— There is indeed nothing to tell.

11. III: The night was by its heavy and sultry heat one of the most uncomfortable of the year— I scarcely slept at all, and found it this morning almost as irksome to write as last Evening. But my draft of a Report must be driven on and my standing task of it now is three pages a day— I went through it this Morning. At the Office I sent for B. Homans, Chief Clerk of the Navy Department; and enquired if there were two public ships, which could be employed at a very early day, one to protect the Sealing and Whaling Settlement on the newly discovered land South of Cape Horn, and the other to go to the Island of St. Thomas and bring home four American Mutineer Seamen, whom N. Levy the Consular Agent has kept in prison there several Months, and whom he cannot send otherwise to the United States— Homans said the latter object might easily be effected; but he had many difficulties to start with regard to the other— The distance; the dangers of an unexplored Coast in that extreme latitude— The dangers of collision with the British; all which I told him we must surmount— He finally said we must wait for one of the Ships from the Mediterranean, perhaps the Guerriere or the Cyane from the Coast of Africa; recalled he said for the misconduct of the Captain Trenchard; who had become intemperate— She is expected daily— I wrote to the President, and to J. Vaughan— There were several heavy Showers, and some thunder; but without thoroughly sweeping or cooling the Atmosphere.

12. IV: Storm of wind and rain the whole Night; but without much change of temperature— I was awake from before one O’Clock, but accidentally rose an hour later than my time— The day was cooler than for some time past; I answered private Letters from my brother, from E. Cruft, and J. Heard junr at Boston; and wrote to the President who has returned to his place Oakhill, in Loudoun County— This Evening I had a visit from Mr Roth the Chargé d’Affaires of France, who has returned from his excursion to Wilmington, and resumes his abode here for the winter— He sets the first example, but I had a Letter from the British Charge des Affaires, Antrobus, announcing his intention to be here on the 17th. and his expectation that the new Minister from England Stratford Canning would arrive by that time.

13. III: A Cool autumnal day, and with it came a capacity of writing at least more comfortably than is possible during the Summer heats. Mr William Lee was at the Office to ask if there was any answer to the last Letter from M. M. Noah, resoliciting an appointment in Europe, and awkwardly apologizing for his book against the President and Mr Madison. I told Lee he might inform Noah that there was no prospect of any such appointment’s being made— I asked Lee what was the usual size of the Bordeaux Hogsheads; but he had nothing but general knowledge about it—that four hogsheads went to a ton; that they should contain 63 Gallons each, but never did quite so much—that those sent to this Country particularly fell short; but that in England they always make deductions for any amount less than 63 Gallons to the Hogshead— On returning home I consulted Kruse’s Contorist, and Kelly’s Cambist for the contents of the Bordeaux Hogshead; and find that they contain usually between 61 and 62 Gallons of 231 cubic inches which makes as exactly as possible 63 Gallons of 224 inches, and adds another spoke to the wheel of my theory— I find also that as the Avoirdupois hundred is of 112 lb. if the 112 is divided by 100 it gives a Pound of 7840 grains Troy weight, rather heavier than that of the Poids de Marc, and with the half Kilogramme tallying much nearer—being exactly 1/4 of an ounce Troy weight heavier— I discover also another curious coincidence between the number of Pounds avoirdupois to a Ton. 2240. and the number of cubic inches to the old Wine-Gallon 224. I know not yet how to account for it; and it perplexes me profoundly— I wrote two Letters to A. Gallatin, and received one from my father.

14. III:30. My morning occupations detained me at home till Noon; having at length undertaken to retrieve the arrears of Journal which have run up to a fortnight— On going to my Office as I passed by the House I have purchased in F. Street, I was surprized to find workmen employed in pulling down the wooden shed, adjoining it— Mrs. Adams has made a contract with a Mason named Van Coble to build an addition to the house; a measure in which I have acquiesced in as much as I have not expressly prevented it— I have been entangled in this and other expenses almost unawares and now to my great concern— While I was at the Office, one of the young Bulfinch’s came, and offered to supply me with lime; and in the Evening there came to me a man to contract for other parts of the building— I am as little satisfied with myself for these things as with the things themselves— My attention to my private concerns ought to be more efficient, not withstanding the pressure of public business.— I wrote a Letter to the President.

15. III: I had gone through my morning task of three pages on my draft of a Report, rather earlier than usual but was detained at home in measuring the contents of three casks, one of which was a Claret Hogshead, one a Beel Barrel, and one a Hogshead of Teneriffe wine which I bought in England— On calculating the contents of the Claret Cask I found it a small fraction short of 58 Gallons— The diameters of the bung and heads were precisely those prescribed in Tarbe’s Manual p. 517. for Casks of 250 litres. The difference was in the length; and I ascertained that to a Cask of those diameters, the length should be 30 inches to contain 63 Gallons— I found also that to reduce english inches and tenths of inches to millimetres, they should be divided by 4. and add 16 to each thousand of the quotient, and to reduce Millimetres to inches and tenths they should be multiplied by four and, 16 to each thousand be deducted from the product— At the Office, W. Elliott of the Patent Office came with the papers of a gauging instrument invented by one Stansbury. It differs in some respects from that of Gunter, which is used by most of our Collectors. I have had Gunter’s gage brought from Georgetown; but neither I nor any one at the Office knows how to use it. But Stansbury’s and Gunter’s are both logarithmic. Mr Frye called to invite me, with Charles to dine with him to-morrow. W. S. Smith was likewise at the Office— I wrote directions for Josias W. King the Clerk in the Office who usually makes up the despatches for our Ministers abroad; with a view to have them transmitted with more punctuality than they hitherto have been.

16. IV: At the Office I wrote nothing— I take no note of time but by its loss— Received Letters from the President and from my wife; the former giving me notice that he intends coming to Washington next Monday; and the latter, that she spends her time so agreeably with her relations at Frederick that she has concluded to postpone her return home till next Tuesday— I dined with Charles at Mr Frye’s. Johnson Hellen was there. Frye spoke to me of a pamphlet, published by Coll. King, an Officer of the army who has been suspended for five years by sentence of a Court Martial, and now addresses to the President these two printed Letters of virulent abuse against the Officers who tried him, and especially against the adjutant General Parker; whom he openly threatens with a visit to Washington— I walked home this Evening with Charles, and we stopped on the way at William S. Smith’s to inform him that he is not to expect his wife home until Tuesday.

17. IV: I have been for several days threatened with indisposition though not absolutely unwell. I have the highest reason to be grateful for the preservation of my health through the Summer, and amidst the laborious occupations with which I am oppressed— Attended Church with Charles— Mr M’Cormick read Prayers for the 16th. Sunday after Trinity, and his Sermon was from Acts XIX.5–6. “When they heard this, they were baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus— And when Paul had laid his hands upon them, the Holy Ghost came upon them.” It was a controversial Sermon, in favour of infant Baptism— This has been made a great sectarian question in the Christian Church, and the antipaedobaptists who pass under the
abridged name of Baptists are one of the most numerous sects in this Country. I have never examined into the grounds of this Country, having always been convinced that it was upon a point not essential, and not worth disputing about. Mr M’Cormick’s discourse justified the practice of infant baptisms on the precept of Christ to his apostles to go and baptise all Nations—arguing that children forming a part of every nation were necessarily included in it—upon the example of Abraham, who on receiving the injunction to circumcised his household, performed the operation on his son Isaac, then only eight days old. He referred also to the order to Moses to sanctify the People, and that they should wash their Apathes at the delivery of the Law, on Sinai— This sanctification he said was by baptism or ablution, and that included all the infants as well as adults— He represented the rite as essential to introduce a person as a member of the Christian Church, and thought if neglected or omitted, although it was inconsistent with the Justice of God to suppose that the Child would be punished, it could not be doubted that those to whom it belonged to perform this office would be— He said that the rite of confirmation was essentially connected with that of baptism; but he should postpone to another day his discourse upon it— I should have been glad to have read and thought further upon the subject after returning home from Church; but the heat of the day, the Mail, the Newspapers, the Journal and the Draft absorbed all the remnant of my time.

18. III:30. The morning hours and the days fly with the wings of lightening— It was again passed noon, when I reached the Office, and then I was reading papers till after two. I took by the President’s directions two sets of papers to Mr Wirt— One of them a complaint from the Spanish Minister, General Vivés, against Captain Trenchard of the Cyane, for taking a Spanish Slave-trader; and the other the papers implicating the Bulloch’s of Savannah. Wirt told me he was going the day after to-morrow for West-Point, to place his Son at the Military Academy there— He also shewed me papers that he had received from Mr Jones the Chief Clerk in the Treasury Department, in the absence of Mr Crawford— It has been advertised that the last instalment of the Louisiana Loan would be paid on the 20th. of October next— The case is that the revenue has fallen so far short that there is not money in the Treasury to make the payment. Jones in Crawford’s absence stated the fact to Cheves, President of the U.S. Bank, enquiring whether the Bank would make the payment for the Government— The Bank are willing, but an Article of their Charter prohibits them from loaning money to the Government beyond half a million without an act of Congress. Cheves presents a plan by which the Bank will furnish the money, and take the Stock, in a form that shall not in law have the effect of a loan to the Government, or of a purchase of the Stock; but which shall in substance be both— He then sends this plan to W. Pinkney of Baltimore for his opinion whether it is feasible— Pinkney gives his opinion upon the whole that it is—in Law— Cheves sends the Case, with the Project of the Bank, and the opinion of Pinkney to Jones, requesting that the opinion of the Attorney General may also be taken upon it— Wirt expressed much surprize that an affair of this importance should be left to be transacted by a Clerk— That Crawford when he left this City on the first of August should not have known of this defalcation of the revenue; or if he knew it, should neither have made provision for meeting the emergency, nor communicated it to the other Commissioners of the sinking fund— I was surprized at it too— I thought, and told Crawford last Winter that the deficiency of the revenue would be more than three Millions— He might just as easily have obtained authority to borrow five; but he did not expect to want more than three, and under the authority given him by a Law to borrow that sum he has yet actually borrowed only two— I concluded that Jones had given notice of this State of things to the President, and that this was one of the occasions of his coming at this time to the City— On returning home, I received a message from him informing me that he had
arrived, and would be glad to see me to-morrow Morning— Mrs Adams’s maid Elizabeth arrived this Evening in the Stage from Frederick— She herself, with her Sister Smith, returns home by the way of Baltimore— This day and Evening were very sultry.

19. III: Accomplishing my morning task somewhat earlier than usual, after calling at my Office I went to the President’s where I found Mr Wirt. He had brought the papers concerning the proposed accomodation to be furnished by the Bank of the United States to the Government; but the President had not heard before, one word of the deficit in the revenue. His motives for coming here were principally relating to the state of our foreign affairs; and chiefly with regard to Portugal and France. I had a conversation of nearly three hours with him upon these points which it is impossible for me to record in detail. With regard to Portugal he seemed inclined to ascribe the hostile aspect of our relations with her in a great measure to the ill-will of the Abbe Correa, to whom he imputed motives not very laudable— The abbe has been upon a visit to Mr Jefferson to whom he talked so much about an American system in which his Government and ours should be united, and by concert with the European powers, should agree to keep the Coasts of this Hemisphere clear of Pirates, on condition that they should sweep the Seas of the Eastern hemisphere clear of Barbary Pirates, that Mr Jefferson had been disposed to favour the project, and thought it might be carried into effect, so that our Squadron might be withdrawn from the Mediterranean.— The President said he had observed to the President that an American system upon that plan would be an alliance between the United States and Portugal against the South-American Independents, which was hardly reconcileable with any just view of our policy, and this was certainly true— I added that the Abbe had more than once broached this subject of an American system to be concerted between the two great Powers of the western Hemisphere; meaning the United States and Portugal— I had never disturbed the abbe in his romancing; but Portugal and the United States are the two great American powers, much as a jolly-boat and the Columbus are two great line of battle-ships—and as to an American System, Independent of Europe, Portugal is neither American nor Independent: So long as Portugal shall recognize the house of Braganza for her Sovereign, so long the house of Braganza will be European and not American; a Satellite and not a primary Planet— As to an American System, we have it; we constitute the whole of it—there is no community of interests or of principles between North and South-America. Mr Torres, and Bolivar and O’Higgins talk about an American system as much as the abbe Correa—but there is no basis for any such system— The President said Mr Jefferson had told the Abbe that as to the appointment of Commissioners to try the captures of Portuguese property by Baltimore pirates, it was out of the question—there could be no such thing— That the Abbe had been exceedingly irritable, and talked under very high excitement; for which Mr Jefferson could not account— I said that in his communications with me here; the Abbe had been mild and moderate— That I believed the subject was very disagreeable to him, and that he was very glad to be relieved from all further agency relating to it— But I had no difficulty in accounting for his excitement and irritability— The Portuguese property taken by the Pirates, notoriously and openly fitted out in Baltimore; officered and manned by our own People was enough to make any man in his situation irritable. The sufferers of course immediately resorted to their Government, and the Government by their Instructions to him— It was my opinion that Portugal had real grounds of complaint against us, and that if the case had been reversed, and we had suffered in the same way, and to the same extent by her People, we should have declared War against her without hesitation. War was not to be dreaded from her—she had too strong an interest against it; but she might assail us by commercial regulations and restrictions, and the Abbe had told me she infallibly would— The President wished me to write to the Abbe and call for his proofs against the naval Officers and judges of the United States whom he has denounced, and also his proofs in all the cases of Portuguese vessels captured by Baltimore Pirates— He
said if there was proof against any of our naval officers they ought to be dismissed; and if against any of the judges, it should be laid before Congress— With regard to France he thought that notwithstanding the resentment of France at our late Tonnage duty, the French Government after satisfying their own pride will conclude to negotiate— He wished me therefore to draw up instructions for Mr Gallatin upon all the points in discussion between the two Countries— The discriminating Tonnage duties, direct and indirect—the Consular Convention—the delivery of deserting Mariners—the Claims of our Citizens upon the French Government—and a claim on the part of France of special privileges in Louisiana— I asked him on what principles the Instructions upon each of these points were to be drawn— I told him what I supposed would be the proposals of France on the Tonnage duties—that is that the duties on both sides should be so proportioned that each party should have half the shipping employed between them— I stated their argument upon it; that upon equal terms they cannot stand a competition with us in navigation, and that the advantages which our navigators have over theirs must in some manner be countervailed to enable them to have their just proportion of the carrying trade— He said he thought there was weight in it; but I observed I did not see how we could possibly assent to the principle. We had offered to all the world entire reciprocity. Great Britain, and several other Nations had accepted the proposal— France now called upon us to agree to be clogged, in order to enable her people to hold competition with us— If we should assent, our own people would first be dissatisfied, and next, all the Nations with which we have stood on terms of reciprocity— We should have clamour and discontent from all quarters. As to the Consular Convention, that, with France was an affair of State— She wanted by means of Consular Jurisdictions, to retain all her power over Frenchmen in this Country— The operation of the system was always odious here— The old Congress had refused to ratify the Convention which had been negotiated by Dr Franklin— Mr Jefferson finally signed one with the Comte de Montmorin; which was the most unpopular Treaty ever made by us— It gave constant dissatisfaction while it lasted, and would be no less disapproved if now renewed. The President thought it would be best to keep the subjects separate, and to postpone the matter of the Consular Convention— That we should agree to the Article for restoring deserting Seamen; and persist in rejecting the claim of privilege in Louisiana— With regard to the claims of our Citizens as there will be no prospect of obtaining any indemnity for them at present, Mr Gallatin should be instructed to endeavour to obtain an article stipulating that they shall be considered hereafter— On returning to my Office I began the draft of Instructions to Mr Gallatin— Mrs Adams and Mrs Smith returned home this day, from Frederick— After a stormy, but very sultry day, the Evening cleared off cold.

20. III:30. I had as visitors at the Office, a Mrs Jones, widow of a man, who obtained a Patent for a machine to make lint— She came to enquire whether the Government would be disposed to purchase half the patent right; for the benefit of the army, and Navy— I told her that she must apply to the War or Navy Department. But as the Secretaries of both those Departments are absent I promised to submit her proposal to the President— Mrs Cornell came with Mr Bestor, to enquire of the fate of her Son— She had been at the President’s but was referred to me, and desired to call there again to-morrow— I requested her to call at the Office before going to the President’s tomorrow, and promised to inform her then of his directions. General Parker came with a new application from Mr Byers of New-York, for a public vessel to protect their Sealing Settlement expedition to the South-Pole— I told him of Homans’s objections but promised to mention the affair again to the
President. Dr. Thornton came to ask if I had laid before the President a Letter which I received from him yesterday soliciting the appointment of Minister to Brazil, in the place of the late Mr John Graham, or if that should not be thought best, then that C. S. Todd should be appointed the Minister there, he the Doctor in Todd’s place to the Republic of Colombia, and Dr. Allison Superintendent of the Patent Office; with an elaborate argument upon the expediency of rewarding long and faithful services— I told the Doctor, that the President had his Letter— I took to the President three despatches received this morning from A. Gallatin; the last subsequent to the two retaliatory ordinances of France, of 26. July. They shew such a change in the aspect of affairs that the draft of Instructions which I began yesterday will no longer suit. I mentioned to the President the substance of the despatches and left them with him— The first of the two ordinances is a retaliatory duty of 90 francs a Ton upon American Vessels entering French Vessels laden— The other gives a bounty of ten franks per hundred Kilogrammes, upon Cotton brought in French Vessels from any part of the two America’s— The objects of this are to obtain a supply of Cotton for their manufactures— To invite evasions of our French Tonnage duty; and to give a premium upon Brazil Cotton— Mr Gallatin does not appear to consider it in that light— It was four O’Clock when I left the President’s, and I lost the day at the Office; for I consider every day as lost in which there is no writing done— I had promised to go with Mrs. Adams to Baltimore, to attend at the Marriage of Susan Buchanan to a Mr Newman, which is to take place to-morrow; but these new Tasks assigned me by the President requiring immediate attention, I was obliged to give it up. Mrs Adams went immediately after dinner to lodge this Night at Ross’s—eleven Miles on the road— She took Charles with her in my place—and also her maid Elizabeth— The Change of weather was so great, that I resumed entire winter raiment, and this Night needed a blanket. The night before last, I could scarcely endure a sheet— I journalized a little, this Evening.

21. III:30. This morning Fahrenheits Thermometer was at 42. and I was so pinched with cold that it was with the utmost difficulty, I could write without a fire— Mrs Cornell with Bestor, and Mrs Jones came again to the Office— I told Mrs Cornell, that the President would now see her—that an immediate pardon could not probably issue; but a further reprieve would probably be granted during which new applications in favour of her son might be made— She said if his life could but be spared he would cheerfully submit to any term of imprisonment. Mrs Jones I referred as the President had directed to the Commissioners of the Navy— At the President’s I found he was preparing to leave the City again to-morrow morning for his seat at Oakhill, in Loudoun County, Virginia. I had a long conversation with him again upon the Instructions to be given to Mr Gallatin. We concluded that the basis of arrangement proposed by Baron Pasquier could not be accepted by us— The motives and principles upon which we arrived at this conclusion are to be stated in the Instructions, for which reason as well as for want of time I shall omit the detail of them here. But it appears to me that the greatest difficulty of our present position is with Spain— When the Session of Congress comes, we shall be still with the Treaty unratified, after threatening measures to take possession of Florida; and postponing them only to give the Cortes an opportunity to do us Justice— The Cortes will do nothing, and the question what we are to do will come upon us with double recoil. The President I found had no inclination to take forcible measures. Symptoms of convulsions in Europe are thickening— The revolution in Spain has been acted over again at Naples— The Emperor of Russia has issued a fulminating declaration against the Spanish Revolution, and Austria is marching troops against that of Naples— A plan of Counter revolution has exploded in Spain and a civil War between Naples and the Island of Sicily appears to be impending. France, England Germany emit volcanic smoke, and time is teeming with another great political earthquake— Our own situation is uncomfortable; our finances disordered; our resources decayed; and tranquility seems in the
view of the President, the pole-star of our policy. Of all political courses the easiest for execution is that which consists in doing nothing— Far niente— But it has a result, which seldom turns to good account; it effects nothing— I told the President that the non-ratification of the Treaty would give no dissatisfaction in this Country, excepting to the persons, whose claims were provided for in it. The Southern and Western People would be glad to have the Treaty set aside. But as Spain will do nothing and is likely to fall into civil War, a movement of the People of Pensacola, and Saint Augustine may be anticipated and might be hastened by which they would assume the Government into their own hands, and then apply to the United States, for protection— Under some such circumstances whether hastened by any agency on our part, or merely waited for, I was convinced we should ultimately be obliged to take possession of Florida, and with it, I thought the recognition of the Republic of Colombia, ought to be simultaneous— The President did not appear to think the time was matured for the recognition of any of the South-American Governments— He told me he should be at Oakhill, ready at any time at a days warning to come to the City— He read me a letter from New-York being an account of his Son in Law Gouverneur’s being dangerously ill with a bilious fever.— There was a Doctor Washington at the Office, who came to ask for a subscription to a medical Miscellany— I was alone at home, morning and Evening; but so occupied that I was scarcely sensible of the lapse of time.

22. III:30.Dr Thornton called upon me this morning at my house, to enquire if there was any prospect of his obtaining a mission to South-America; as, if there was, he was desirous of perfecting himself in the Spanish Language. The Doctor is a native of the Island of Tortola; a Man of learning, ingenuity, wit and humour; well meaning, good-natured, and mainly honest, but without judgment or discretion. I told him there would probably not be an early appointment of a Minister at Rio Janeiro— The President left the City this morning. I began anew a draft of Instructions to A. Gallatin, but was much engaged with a book sent me by J. Vaughan from Philadelphia— W. Clarke upon Saxon and English Coins, Weights and Money; I found it contained much information tending to confirm some of my opinions, as well as to shake others— Journalized and read the Papers in the Evening.

23. IV:30. Since the Evenings have grown cool, and I am enabled both to write and read with candles, I make later hours then, and later rising the next morning follows— I yet wrote three pages of my draft, before going to my Office; and had therefore little time there— A Mr Howland from Alexandria came to solicit again the appointment of Mr Bennett as Consul at Pernambuco, and said he was despatching a vessel to that place, which was to sail in a week or ten days, and in which Mr Bennett could take passage, if he should receive the appointment. I told him that the President had postponed his determination in this case, but that I would write to him, on Monday or Tuesday concerning it. J. C. Jones of Boston wrote me some time since a Letter; soliciting the appointment of his Son, as commercial agent to the Sandwich Islands. Several other merchants of Boston have joined in the recommendation, and there appears to be a considerable commerce carried on between the United States and those Islands, the Savages of which have made such rapid advances in civilization, that they have almost acquired a right to be acknowledged as legitimate Sovereign powers— I sent Mr Jones this day the Commission for his Son, which is a Certificate from the Department of State, addressed to all whom it may concern, and constituting him Agent for Commerce and Seamen; and I wrote to the young man, requesting him to communicate frequently to the department, all useful information, concerning the Islands and their inhabitants— The progress of their civilization, and the nature and modes of the traffic with them— I also wrote something further of the draft of Instructions to A. Gallatin— I still correspond with the Marshals on the subject of the Census; but Colvin now writes all the Letters, the substance of which I verbally give him— He is the only Clerk in the Department who can do this with ease and expedition; and whose drafts seldom require much alteration upon revisal— On returning home to dinner, I found Mrs Adams returned from the wedding at Baltimore. She was not well— Charles had taken a severe cold, and the Coachman, had a high fever, and took immediately to his bed.

24. IV:30.Mrs Adams and Charles being both too unwell to go out, I attended Church at Mr M’Cormick’s alone. He read prayers for the 17th. Sunday after Trinity, and preached the remnant of his discourse of the last Sunday; from the same text. Acts XIX.5–6— That text however has reference only to baptism, and not to confirmation. There is no warrant in the New testament for the rite of Confirmation, however proper it may be for practice. It seems in the Episcopal churches to be a ceremony performed only by the bishops, and is not used at all in the democracy of our congregational Churches. Mr M’Cormick’s sermon consisted chiefly of an analysis and commentary upon the ceremony as prescribed in the Book of Common Prayer. He urged with suitable earnestness the obligation, resting upon every individual to learn the duties imposed upon him by his baptismal vows, to confirm them by his own solemn promise, and to perform them in faithfulness and Sincerity— From the composition of this Sermon, I should suppose it was one of his own— It had nothing of the compass, depth, or Splendour of the Sermon upon the Sabbath— It was certainly not be the same hand— Mr M’Cormick gave notice that next Sunday being the first Sabbath of the Month, he should catechise the Children before the Morning Service— On returning home from Church, I found Mrs Adams ill in bed with a sick head-ache which confined her the remainder of the day— I had a mail, with long despatches from J. Forsyth 20 July at Madrid, and from C. S. Todd at Juan Griego, Island of Margaritta. My Journal absorbed the remnant of the day, and the newspapers of the Evening. Mr. and Mrs. W. S. Smith were here after dinner.

25. III:30. Arrears of Journal redeemed. Dr Thornton called this Morning at my house. In the prosecution of my enquiries into weights and measures, I find a curiosity to ascertain the relative specific gravity of several liquids; I took a small glass vial with a glass stopper and weighed it at the scales at my Office; filled with water from my pump. The Vial full weighed in both Scales the large and the small 2768 1/2 Grams Troy— The vial empty 1730, and the Water poured into another vessel 1034. There was therefore a loss in the pouring out, of 4 1/2 Grains. My experiments must of course be very imperfect as I have no means of weighing the substances in vacuo, or in water—but as my vial contains a little more than 1000 Grains Troy of pump water, I hope to be able to ascertain by it with tolerable precision, the comparative gravities of many other liquids. Baron Stackelberg the Swedish Chargé d’Affaires, was at the Office having returned last Evening from his Summer tour to Niagara, Ballstown, and Saratoga Springs— He told me that Mr. Antrobus came with him, but went off again this Morning to Annapolis— Mr Canning has arrived in the Spartan Frigate at Norfolk. I wrote a short Letter to the President— Dr. Huntt was here. Mrs. Adams continues very unwell, and the Coachman has a severe fever— Mr Petry the French Consul called this Evening and left a Letter from Madame de Neuville to Mrs. Adams, but did not stop. The Letter is dated 12 July, a day or two after her arrival at Paris.

26. III:30. I received a Letter from the President recommending that a Note should be written to the Abbe Correa, positively rejecting his proposal, for the appointment of Commissioners to concert and adjust with the Portuguese Ministers the complaints of Portuguese subjects against the Pirates under Artigan colours fitted out from the United States. I immediately made a draft of a Note, and wrote a short Letter to the President, enclosing it for his revisal— The Abbe’s notes have I think given us advantages in this controversy independent of the merits of our Cause. The President is more anxious than I should be to make the most of the Abbe’s bad management. I do it with reluctance. I think we have something to answer for to Portugal in this case on the score of Justice, and that we shall answer for it soon or late by our own sufferings— I reluct at the idea, of supporting our Cause, upon the weakness or maladdress of the Adversary’s counsel— Edward Wyer came to the Office, for an authentication of a power of Attorney. I weighed my Vial full of Whiskey, and found it weigh 970 Grains—whence, assuming my pump water as 1000. the specific gravity of Whiskey is 935— Mrs Adams is yet confined to her bed. Mary Hellen came home from Mrs Frye’s— Mrs. W. S. Smith was here.

27. II:45.Mrs. Adams who was quite ill in the Night called me up, and after rousing her maid Elizabeth, I did not return to bed, but sat down to my draft of a Report upon weights and measures— At the Office I weighed my vial full of red Provence wine, and found it weighed 1028 Grains which was to the water as 990 to 1000. The French Annuaire du Bureau des Longitudes, gives the weight of wine to distilled Water as 9939 to 10000. and Burgundy wine as 9915— As pump water is heavier than distilled, the proportions given by my experiment are as correct as I could have expected and give an average proportion of 99 to 100 for the specific gravities of Claret wine and Water— Mr T. Worthington formerly a Senator from the State of Ohio, and afterwards its Governor called at the Office— He has been for some years retired from Public life, and is now an army Contractor— I had not seen him since the year 1807— He is going to see the President in Virginia to-morrow— I finished the Draft of a Letter of Instruction to A. Gallatin— Mr Canning the British Minister arrived in the city this Morning.

28. IV:30.Mr Daniel Brent called this morning at my house, which belongs to him— We are to remove from it the first of next Month, and he has already rented it to Davis the keeper of the Hotel— Mr Brent however informed me that as Mrs Adams was unwell, and it might be inconvenient for us to remove exactly at the day, we might suit our own convenience in that respect— Coll. Freeman had called yesterday at the Office, and mentioned to me that he had a French Half-metre, that he would lend me— He came this morning and brought a complete set of French long measures, which were brought out as standards to Louisiana by the Prefect Laussat in 1802; and after the cession of the Province to us, were given by the French Consul to Coll. Freeman; who was there in command as a Military Officer of the United States. He gave him also the set of weights and of measures of capacity; but these he has lost; or they have been stolen from him— The Metre is a brass bar of one piece in a wooden box bed— That and the half-metre have the name of Lenoir engraved upon them, and he was no doubt the maker. There is a small brass ruler of two decimetres, divided into Centimetres and Millimetres, but without the name of Lenoir. The double Metre or Toise is of wood— Two Staffs with ivory pommels and made to be jointed together. The chain for surveying is of iron; I did not examine it— I borrowed them all of Coll. Freeman, to measure them with Troughton’s beam compasses— W. Elliot of the patent Office came, with an explanation of Gunter’s, Everett’s and Stansbury’s gauging instruments: and he entered with me into some elucidations of Callet’s Logarithmic Tables. He is to shew me an instrument of his own invention, which he thinks superior to any logarithms for calculation— These operations however consumed much of my time. I weighed again my vial of Claret wine, first in the vial; then in the cup; and then again in the vial— There was no variation of the weight; but there was a loss of about 4-grains at each pouring out from one vessel to the other— And I found that the Water which has been standing four days in the cup had lost about 3 penny-weight, or 1/15 by evaporation— This suggested to me a new train of experiments for which I have not the time— I found that the Brass Metre was at least 39.4 inches of my Gunter’s scale. I took home with me the two decimetre rule, and found it in similar proportion to my Measures there; but very well corresponding with the brass Pied de Roi, graduated on the other side in Millimetres which Montreal gave me at St. Petersburg. I wrote only one short Letter, and began one to the President; but it was six O’Clock when I got home to dinner— Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith were here. Mrs Adams is still confined to her bed.

29. IV:30. I received this morning a Letter from Mr Stratford Canning, informing me that he had arrived late last Evening in the City with a Credential Letter as Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary from the King of Great-Britain, of which together with the Letter of recall of Sir Charles Bagot, he enclosed copies; and requesting me to appoint an hour to receive him; and to take the pleasure of the President, when he would give him an audience to deliver the Letters; at which time also Mr Antrobus would take leave. I immediately sent word to Mr Canning that I would receive him at the Office of the Department at three O’Clock this day; at which hour he came, with Mr Antrobus— I told him I should immediately transmit his Letter and the copies of the two Royal Letters to the President in Virginia, and on receiving
his answer would give notice to Mr Canning of the time when the President would see him. He said he should be ready to go to the Presidents in Virginia, or to await his return to this City as would best suit the President’s convenience— I told him the President would very shortly return to the City, and would probably receive him here— That in the mean time, if he had any business to transact he might consider himself as accredited, and I should be happy to receive and give immediate attention to any Communication from him— The Conversation then turned upon indifferent topics— The Spartan Frigate in which he came had touched at the Island of Madeira where they stopped three days— They met there the United States Cyane, Captain Trenchard, which incident gave occasion to some allusion to the Slave trade— He said he hoped to have some conversation with me on that subject— I told him I had been led to expect this, and should be happy to meet in this respect the views of his Government. I wrote a short Letter to the President; one to T. B. Wait at Boston; and the draft of a Letter to J. J. Appleton at Rio de Janeiro from whom I received two despatches— Mrs W. S. Smith was here. Mrs Adams yet very ill.

30. III.45. I had visits at the Office from Nathl. H. Strong, General R. Swartwout, Dr Kirkpatrick, Mr Cutts and Mr Antrobus. Strong was the person who in April 1814. came as a bearer of despatches to St. Petersburg, and brought me instructions to go to Gothenburg for the negotiation of Peace. He has been roaming about the world, ever since, and came last about five months since from Buenos-Ayres. Swartwout and Kirkpatrick are just from New-York— Kirkpatrick was formerly a member of Congress from New-York, and I had been then acquainted with him but did not remember him. Mr Cutts came to tell me that he and his family were evacuating the house in F. Street into which we are to remove, and would be ready to deliver the keys this Evening or Monday Morning. I told him I would send for them on Monday. Antrobus came from Mr Canning, with a request that I would appoint a time to see him and I fixed Monday at two O’Clock— I wrote to the President— Mrs W. S. Smith was at our house— Mrs Adams still keeps her bed.

Day. The range of my rising hour has been from three quarters past two to three quarters past four. The average about four. The summer heats continued through the first half of the Month, and it was irksome to read or write by Candle-light— I then retired to bed between eight and nine of the Evening, and rose between three and four. As the Evenings have grown cooler I make them longer, retire at ten and rise between four and five. I sit down immediately to my draft and am employed till near noon, writing three pages— Then the journal of the preceding day, and reach my Office seldom before one. My attempt to get there earlier has again failed for I found that once there, I had no command of my occupation, but was compelled to give my time to the current business of the Office— Between five and six I come home to dinner, and in the Evening read the newspapers. I have no leisure.
